tests.name: array-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: array variable substitution
# Array elements accessed with parentheses

set arr(key) value
puts $arr(key)
set arr(x) hello
set arr(y) world
puts "$arr(x) $arr(y)"

tests.name: backslash-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: backslash escape sequences
# Common escape sequences in double quotes

puts "hello\tworld"
puts "line1\nline2"
puts "back\\slash"

tests.name: backslash-1.2
tests.script:
# Test: backslash escapes special chars
# Escape dollar and bracket to prevent substitution

puts "literal \$var"
puts "literal \[cmd\]"
puts "quote: \""

tests.name: backslash-1.3
tests.script:
# Test: backslash-newline continuation
# Backslash-newline becomes space

puts "hello \
world"
puts "one\
two"

tests.name: cmd-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: basic command substitution
# Square brackets execute command and substitute result

puts [string length hello]
puts [string toupper abc]

tests.name: cmd-1.2
tests.script:
# Test: command substitution in double quotes
# Command substitution works inside quotes

puts "length: [string length test]"
puts "upper: [string toupper hello]"

tests.name: cmd-1.3
tests.script:
# Test: nested command substitution
# Commands can be nested

puts [string toupper [string tolower ABC]]
puts [string length [string repeat x 5]]

tests.name: cmd-1.4
tests.script:
# Test: command substitution with variable
# Variables work inside command substitution

set x hello
puts [string length $x]
puts [string toupper $x]

tests.name: mixed-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: mixed substitutions
# All substitution types in one string

set name world
puts "hello $name, len=[string length $name]\ttab"

tests.name: nosubst-1.1
substcmd-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: subst command basic usage
# The subst command performs substitutions on a string

set x hello
puts [subst {$x world}]
puts [subst {length is [string length abc]}]

tests.name: substcmd-1.2
tests.script:
# Test: subst command with flags
# Disable specific substitution types

set x hello
puts [subst -nocommands {$x [string length foo]}]
puts [subst -novariables {$x [string length foo]}]

tests.name: var-1.1
tests.script:
# Test: basic variable substitution
# Dollar sign substitutes variable value

set x hello
puts $x
set y world
puts $y

tests.name: var-1.2
tests.script:
# Test: braced variable names
# Braces delimit variable name exactly

set name value
puts ${name}
set abc 123
puts ${abc}def

tests.name: var-1.3
tests.script:
# Test: variable in double quotes
# Variables substituted inside double quotes

set a hello
set b world
puts "$a"
puts "$a $b"
puts "say $a to $b"
tests.stdout:
hello
hello world
say hello to world

tests.name: var-1.4
tests.script:
# Test: undefined variable error
# Accessing undefined variable is an error

puts $undefined
tests.stderr:
can't read "undefined": no such variable
    while executing
"puts $undefined"
    (file "spec/tests/subst/var-1.4.tcl" line 4)
